name: NPR
text:
The powerful derecho that swept through the Midwest in August is officially the most costly thunderstorm event in recorded U.S. history, costing $7.5 billion worth of damage — and counting.  
 https://t.co/wgL8a121Ze

name: NPR
text: After his theft of hedge clippers in 1997 landed him a life sentence, Fair Wayne Bryant's story became a cause célèbre for the perceived unfairness of "three-strikes laws." https://t.co/wFtyxLDMGz

name: NPR
text: Joe Biden's campaign manager cautioned supporters not to get complacent: "The very searing truth is that Donald Trump can still win this race." https://t.co/0H9FHHoYBC

name: NPR
text: TikTok is expanding its ban on QAnon to include all content that advances the conspiracy theory, following a previous enforcement that targeted specific hashtags. https://t.co/be84MYtwqo

name: NPR
text: Thousands of demonstrators gathered in solidarity in French cities on Sunday, as the number of people detained in connection with the history teacher's beheading rose to 11. https://t.co/jkRAWQuSyH

name: NPR
text: Bigger and more destructive wildfires are on the rise in the U.S., driven in great part by a changing climate. More than 40 million Americans live in high-risk zones. Here's how to find out if you're one of them. https://t.co/0lZXHm60VF

name: NPR
text:
When his grandmother died in Israel this year, his family couldn't travel to the funeral. So he began photographing his mother as a way to help understand the grieving process.

"Watching her emotions change day to day, helped me heal along with her."
https://t.co/T95hePLdto

name: NPR
text:
Donnel Baird's company makes energy-saving updates to buildings almost exclusively in low-income areas. Cutting the carbon footprint saves money — and fights climate change.

"Solar panels aren't just for rich people," he says. "They're for everybody." 
https://t.co/5pswwuMSTc
